item.title: Amazon Quietly Dumps the Forerunner 265, Now Selling the Garmin Watch for Pocket Change
item.content:encoded:
You don‚Äôt need to spend $1,100 on the latest Fenix 8 to get a serious running watch that tracks everything you need. The sweet spot in Garmin‚Äôs lineup has always been the Forerunner series, and for good reason: these watches outsell everything else in the brand‚Äôs catalog. The Forerunner 265 is the most premium and popular model in the range and packs a brilliant AMOLED display and advanced training metrics that rival watches costing twice as much. Amazon just quietly marked it down to $299, slashed from its usual $449 price tag. That‚Äôs an all-time low for a watch that delivers fantastic running features without the extreme price of Garmin‚Äôs flagship models.

See at Amazon

Why Runners Keep Picking This Watch

The difference is apparent from the very first moments you fire up the Forerunner 265: that brilliant AMOLED touchscreen pops with color and sharp text which remains quite readable under direct sunlight, joined by traditional button controls that work beautifully when your hands are sweaty or you‚Äôre wearing gloves. The 46mm size makes the watch feather-light on your wrist so you just about forget it‚Äôs there on those ultra-long runs-or really through most of the day. Get up to 13 days of battery life in smartwatch mode and up to 20 hours in GPS mode to give you plenty of juice for training weeks.

Your day begins with a personalized report which provides context for how to approach each and every training day. Upon waking, you get an overview of your sleep quality, recovery status, and training outlook alongside HRV status, training readiness, and local weather. This information helps you decide if today is the day to push hard or if your body needs an easier session. The training readiness score brings together sleep quality, recovery, training load, and HRV status to tell you if you‚Äôre primed to go hard and get the most out of your workout.

Race preparation becomes strategic with personalized daily suggested workouts. You input your target race and course details into the Garmin Connect app, and the watch creates training plans that adapt after every run to match your current performance and recovery status. The race widget on your watch keeps your goal front and center while the workouts adapt as your body responds to training.

Multi-band GNSS technology with SatIQ provides accuracy in positioning that more affordable watches simply cannot attain. This matters when you‚Äôre running in areas with tall buildings, heavy tree cover, or challenging terrain where the basic GPS signals struggle. Optimizing this accuracy for battery life means you won‚Äôt be sacrificing runtime to get accurate distance and pace. You have more than 30 built-in activity profiles for running, triathlon, cycling, open-water swimming, and lots more.

Safety features add peace of mind during solo training sessions. Incident detection works during select outdoor activities and sends a message with your live location to emergency contacts when paired with your compatible smartphone. The Assistance feature lets you manually trigger an alert when you need help, something that is good to have when you are exploring new routes or training in remote areas.

At $299, you‚Äôre getting a watch that competes directly with models costing $600 or more.

item.title: Subnautica 2 Publisher Encourages Voluntary Layoffs As It Goes ‚ÄòAI First‚Äô
item.content:encoded:
Some of the biggest games of the year are getting new difficulty options. Some of the biggest companies would kindly like their workers to quietly leave. Welcome to another edition of Morning Checkpoint, Kotaku‚Äòs daily round-up of gaming news and culture. This Lego arcade is one of my favorite new proposed fan sets. It would go perfectly in that giant Lego city I have no time or money for building in my attic.

Krafton will let developers voluntarily resign as it doubles down on AI

The PUBG and Subnautica 2 publisher will allow employees based in South Korea to be part of a new voluntary resignation program that gives anywhere from six months to three years of severance, Business Korea reports. Krafton says the plan isn‚Äôt aimed at sneaking through ‚Äúsoft‚Äù layoffs, but is ‚Äúto support members in proactively designing their growth direction and embarking on new challenges both inside and outside the company amid the era of AI transformation,‚Äù according to a translation by Automaton.

The news comes after Krafton committed $70 million in investment for GPU clusters to drive its agentic AI transformation and as fellow South Korea publisher Nexon suggested adopting generative AI technology is a matter of survival.

220 GTA 6 devs signed a letter blasting the firing of 31 colleagues

The IGWB trade union group in the UK announced on Thursday that the letter was delivered to Rockstar management. It accused the company of union busting and demanded the reinstatement of the previously fired developers. French union STJV is planning a protest in front of Take-Two France on Friday.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs heartwarming to see so many of our colleagues supporting us and holding management to account‚Äîduring a period where Rockstar want us to feel scared, my brave former colleagues are marching straight up to our boss‚Äôs door and demanding our voices are heard and not backing down,‚Äù one of the fired employees said in a statement. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs clear to everyone close to this situation that this is a blatant, unapologetic act of vicious union busting. Rockstar employs so many talented game developers, all of whom are crucial to making the games we put out.‚Äù

Could GTA 6‚Äòs delay also delay the launch of the PS6?

That‚Äôs the thought experiment one recently analyst proposed. ‚ÄúWe are currently forecasting a next-gen PlayStation and Xbox to arrive in late 2027‚Äìbut might the console companies be tempted to get more from the current console generation by riding the GTA 6 wave and waiting until 2028?‚Äù Ampere Analysis research director Piers Harding-Rolls posed the idea to GamesIndustry.biz. ‚ÄúThe fact that games are now cross-gen makes this less of a factor, perhaps, but such is the size of the GTA franchise, the launch timing will get all areas of the games business thinking about their product strategies.‚Äù

The idea here is that GTA 6 will lead to a spike in new console sales that will dramatically increase the current-gen install base. If that peak doesn‚Äôt come until early 2027, console makers might have an incentive to wait a bit before pushing out their next hardware release. But as Harding-Rolls also points out, backwards compatibility makes that less of an issue these days.

Silent Hill f just got a new easy mode

Patch 1.10 added a ‚Äúcasual‚Äù difficulty for players who are tired of messing around with the Souls-y action combat and just want to experience the world and story. It also fixes bugs on PC and makes the New Game + experience much more brisk.

Steam hit Clover Pit, meanwhile, is getting a new hard mode

A new update celebrating 1 million sales adds a new difficulty that features double the deadline amount. These are the horror slot machine game‚Äòs equivalent of Balatro‚Äòs blinds. The full 1.2 patch notes list tons of other tweaks, balance changes, and bug fixes.

  • Bowser, Jr.‚Äôs eyes look all kinds of messed up in the first Mario Galaxy Movie trailer
  • Hideo Kojima just did the most Ubisoft thing ever

item.title: Ben Starr Dubbing A Pok√©mon Scene Proves Why Fans Are Desperate For Voice Acting
item.content:encoded:
Pok√©mon Legends: Z-A is the latest monster-taming RPG in the series to forgo voice acting. As these games have become more cinematic, it‚Äôs become pretty jarring that these characters don‚Äôt have voices when they speak. Z-A has fully animated scenes in which characters‚Äô mouths flap as they speak, but no sound actually comes out. As such, fans have been making their own voice dubs of the series for years, and there are some pretty good ones out there. There‚Äôs also a deeply unserious one by Final Fantasy XVI and Clair Obscur: Expedition 33 actor Ben Starr playing Naveen from Legends: Z-A completely straight with his usual broody delivery.

In a recent episode of the Kit & Krysta Podcast, Starr ‚Äúauditioned‚Äù for the role, with co-hosts Kit Ellis and Krysta Yang acting alongside him as the protagonist and Taunie. Starr, hilariously, makes no attempt to capture Naveen‚Äôs youth and pretty much whips out his gravely Clive voice from Final Fantasy XVI. If you‚Äôve ever wanted to hear Starr be a broody simp for a Pok√©mon streamer, here‚Äôs your chance.

It‚Äôs a funny bit and I have to applaud the artistic choices made with a mostly straight face here, but it does underline that a lot of the character of these games can be dialed up and enhanced with a good voice actor in the booth. Legends: Z-A definitely shows that Game Freak has the writing chops to execute some really funny, memorable scenes and jokes despite not including voice acting, but every time I hear a fan try to embody these characters, I just wish the games had that same spark we get in projects like the Pok√©mon anime or the Detective Pikachu games. Legends: Z-A takes a baby step toward this future by giving your main character Link-like grunts and yells when they do some actions, but they‚Äôre one person in a city full of heroes and villains that I‚Äôd love to hear speak instead of just reading. Don‚Äôt get me started on that weird scene in Sword and Shield where a whole concert was happening just for a character to pantomime the performance instead of singing. Though that‚Äôs also allowed fans to interpret that character‚Äôs musical chops, as well.

item.title: Please, Just Stop Accusing Us Of Copying Expedition 33, Begs RPG Developer
item.content:encoded:
Clair Obscur: Expedition 33 is certainly one of 2025‚Äôs big success stories, but you‚Äôd be hard-pressed to call its concept wholly original. Sandfall Interactive‚Äôs turn-based RPG may well have been first to combine fully real-time movement with turn-based combat, but it was built on the shoulders of games like Yakuza: Like a Dragon, Atelier Ryza and even Mario RPG and Paper Mario, along with a wealth of other influences (Final Fantasy, Persona, Earthbound‚Ä¶). So when another studio independently developers a turn-based RPG with real-time dodge and parry mechanics, it‚Äôs hardly a given that it‚Äôs lifting directly from this year‚Äôs hit. Yet this is the accusation The Time I Have Left is being bombarded with, and it‚Äôs really getting developer Ground down.

The forthcoming RPG, which describes itself as ‚Äúa time-driven escape adventure with RPG elements,‚Äù has had its most recent demo available on Steam for just over a month, and it‚Äôs been mostly been well-received by players, albeit with the qualification that combat is rather ‚Äúclunky‚Äù‚Äîa term used by an awful lot of Steam reviews. However, it‚Äôs a different criticism that‚Äôs bothering developers Ground, and that‚Äôs the suggestion that its copying Expedition 33. Something the team suggests would be a tricky feat, given demos of its game were playable in 2022, some three years before the French success was released.

‚ÄúEvery time someone accuses us of ripping off Expedition 33, we die a little bit inside,‚Äù the team wrote on X and BlueSky. ‚ÄúYes, it‚Äôs a turn-based RPG,‚Äù the post continues, and ‚ÄúYes, it has dodges and parries.‚Äù But, the developers implore readers, ‚Äúour game already had all that in the public demos we released in 2022 and 2024.‚Äù The post concludes, ‚ÄúNo need to call us names.‚Äù

Every time someone accuses us of ripping off Expedition 33, we die a little bit inside.

Yes, it's a turn-based RPG.
Yes, it has dodges and parries.

Our game already had all that in the public demos we released in 2022 and 2024.
No need to call us namesü´† pic.twitter.com/zhe5XKQyQ4

‚Äî The Time I Have Left‚è≥Demo OUT NOW (@ground_ga) November 12, 2025

Rather cannily, the post also features a brief trailer for the indie game and its fantastic red, black, and white aesthetic, which has hopefully drawn in a whole bunch of new eyes after the tweet went gently viral. The developers later noted their delight at the supportive response they‚Äôve received to this, with almost 1,000 replies so far.

Ground hasn‚Äôt had a particularly easy time of late. The studio itself went bankrupt earlier in the year, but the entire staff has continued on developing the game while seeking more support, and has still managed to put out the new demo. And given the popularity of Clair Obscur: Expedition 33, it‚Äôd make some degree of sense for publishers to take note of this one, given there‚Äôs a pre-built audience out there right now.

The Time I Have Left features imbalanced combat in which enemies get more actions per turn than you, but you have multiple ways to influence the fight during their moves. There are parries and dodges, but also interrupts, counters, and even ways to gain more turns for yourself, with different suites of direct control in both phases of battles. The developers welcome feedback on the demo on Steam, although perhaps avoid mentioning you-know-what if you do.
